Linear Projection & Conditional Expectation
y
  2022-05-17 21:09:44 2022-05-17 21:09  
  • review

Conditional Expectation, Linear Projection, Regression, Normal Distibution and Matrix Decomposition are all connected.

The purpose of this page is to review (mostly to remind myself of) topics related to conditional expectations and linear projections of random variables. Before we begin, a few key notations:

  • ′’′ is used to represent the transpose operator.
  • ⃗ \vec { } \   is used to represent a vector. Unless stated otherwise, we assume a column vector.

Illustration of Conditional Expectation and Linear Projection

The content of this section can be summarised using the illustrated plots below.

codes

  • left: For normal distributions, the conditional expectation and the linear projection with a constant term are the same.
  • right: In general, it is not the case.

On Conditional Expectation

following this…

Probability Density Functions

First, recall the probability density function…

Note: For discrete random variables, it is more appropriate to use term probability mass function…

  • Consider two discrete random variables XXX and YYY.
  • joint pdf (or pmf with m = mass): p(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y)p(x,y) = P(X=x, Y=y)p(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y)
  • marginal pdf:
    • pX(x)=P(X=x)=∑yp(x,y)p_X(x) = P(X=x) = \sum_{y} p(x,y)pX​(x)=P(X=x)=∑y​p(x,y)
    • pY(y)=P(Y=y)=∑xp(x,y)p_Y(y) = P(Y=y) = \sum_{x} p(x,y)pY​(y)=P(Y=y)=∑x​p(x,y)
  • conditional pdf:
    pY∣X(y∣x)=P(Y=y∣X=x)=p(x,y)pX(x)p_{Y|X}(y|x) = P(Y=y|X=x) = \displaystyle \frac{p(x,y)}{p_X(x)}pY∣X​(y∣x)=P(Y=y∣X=x)=pX​(x)p(x,y)​

Definition

The conditional expectation of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is defined as
E[Y∣X=x]=∑yypY∣X(y∣x).E[Y|X=x] = \sum_{y} y p_{Y|X}(y|x).E[Y∣X=x]=y∑​ypY∣X​(y∣x).
So, E[Y∣X]E[Y|X]E[Y∣X] is a function of XXX.

Properties

Straightforward to prove the following properties

  • tower rule:
    E[E[Y∣X,Z]∣X]=E[Y∣X]E[E[Y|X,Z]|X] = E[Y|X]E[E[Y∣X,Z]∣X]=E[Y∣X]
  • special cases:
    • expectation of conditional expectation = expectation
      E[E[Y∣X]]=E[Y]E[E[Y|X]] = E[Y]E[E[Y∣X]]=E[Y]
    • conditional expectation of conditional expectation = conditional expectation
      E[E[Y∣X]∣X]=E[Y∣X]E[E[Y|X]|X] = E[Y|X]E[E[Y∣X]∣X]=E[Y∣X]
  • conditioning is to freeze the conditioning variable. so, for a 1D function hhh:
    E[h(X)Y∣X]=h(X)E[Y∣X].E[h(X)Y|X] = h(X)E[Y|X].E[h(X)Y∣X]=h(X)E[Y∣X].

Mean Squared Error and Best Predictor

The conditional expectation E(Y∣X)E(Y|X)E(Y∣X) is the minimizing function of the mean squared error

over 1D functions fff. Thus, the conditional expectation is the best predictor of YYY given XXX.

To prove it is surprisingly easy. Denoting h(X)=E(Y∣X)−f(X)h(X) = E(Y|X) - f(X)h(X)=E(Y∣X)−f(X),
we have

since the last term is zero:

due to the tower rule.

On Linear Projection

Following Chapter 4, Time Series Analysis by Hamilton…

Settings:

  • XXX and YYY are as before except XXX is assumed to be a random vector, represented as X⃗\vec XX.
  • Often, one of its entries is a constant 111.

Definition

Given X⃗\vec XX, the prediction function for YYY is restricted to a linear function in XXX:

where α\alphaα is a vector parameter.

The linear projection of YYY on X⃗\vec XX is defined as

such that

For an illustration how the linear projection compares to the conditional expectation, go to the top of this page.

Solution: From the definition, the solution of the linear projection is

Notation: Hamilton uses the hat notation (^\hat{ }^) to differentiate it from the conditional expectation.

  • P^(Y∣X⃗)\hat{P}(Y|\vec X)P^(Y∣X): linear projection of YYY into X⃗\vec XX.
  • E^(Y∣X⃗)\hat{E}(Y|\vec X)E^(Y∣X): linear projection of YYY into X⃗\vec XX with a constant term, i.e.
    E^(Y∣X⃗):=P^(Y∣X⃗,1)\hat{E}(Y|\vec X) := \hat{P}(Y|\vec X, 1)E^(Y∣X):=P^(Y∣X,1)

Properties

  • Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Best Prediction: The linear projection produces the smallest mean squared error among all linear predictions. The proof, resembling that for conditional expectation, is simple.

  • Gaussian and Conditional Expectation: If the random vectors X⃗\vec XX and Y⃗\vec YY are Gaussian, the conditional probability is also a Gaussian with the mean and the covariance equal to the linear projection and MSE.

  • Linear Regression: Consider an ordinary least square regression:

    where ′x⃗i’\vec x_i′xi​ is the iii-th observation.
    The linear projection solution in () paralles the solution

Other Transformation toward Uncorrelated Variables

Through the triangular factorisation, A−1Z⃗A^{-1} \vec{Z}A−1Z has a diagonal second moment matrix, i.e. its components are uncorrelation. In this section, we consider two other transformations to map Z⃗\vec{Z}Z into a vector with a diagonal second moment matrix.

Transformations

Cholesky factorisation: From the triangular factorisation, we can easily derive

Then, P−1Z⃗P^{-1} \vec{Z}P−1Z has the identity matrix as its second moment matrix.

Diagonalisation: Since Ω\OmegaΩ is a non-negative-definite symmetric matrix, it is diagonisable

where Λ\LambdaΛ is a diagonal matrix and VVV is orthonormal: VV′=V′V=IV V’ = V’ V = IVV′=V′V=I (thus V−1=V′V^{-1} = V’V−1=V′). Thus, V−1Z⃗V^{-1} \vec{Z}V−1Z has Λ\LambdaΛ as its second moment matrix. (of course, the diagonal of Λ\LambdaΛ is made up with eigenvalues and the columns of VVV are eigenvectors.)

Note: This is nothing but the principal component analysis (PCA)!

Mapping Illustration

Each transformation (which is nothing but a matrix multiplication) can be understood as a mapping of two basis vectors into the standard unit vectors:

The plot below is an illustration of this mapping.

  • The scatter data are generated from a bivariate normal vector with zero mean and

  • For each plot:

    • the blue and red lines correspond to Z⃗1\vec{Z}_1Z1​ and Z⃗2\vec{Z}_2Z2​, respectively.
    • A unit circle and an inscribing square are shown to guage the length of the basis vectors.

  • Observations:

    • triangular: The kkk-th element of the kkk-th basis vector is 1 (as they touch the square). The second basis vector is the second unit vector.
    • Cholesky: The lenghth of each basis vector indicates the dispersion of the data along its direction.
    • diagonalisation: The basis vectors have a unit length and are orthogonal to each other.
